revision.comment: /* External links */ remove {{SouthAustralia-geo-stub}} because {{SouthAustralia-protected-area-stub}} is a stub within a sub-category
revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox Australian place | type = protected | name = Minlacowie Conservation Park | state = sa | iucn_category = vi | image = | caption = | image_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|34|52|57|S|137|39|10|E|display=inline,title}} | force_national_map = | relief = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | map_alt = | nearest_town_or_city = [[Stansbury, South Australia|Stansbury]]. | area = {{convert|28|ha|acres|abbr=on}}{{cite web|title=Protected Areas Information System - reserve list (as of 17 Feb 2014)|url=http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/b88e6e26-4bd9-4c68-8fff-9e800114eb69/park-management-protected-areas-gen.pdf|publisher=Department of Environment Water and Natural Resources|accessdate=26 March 2014|pages=}} | area_footnotes = | established = 14 February 2008 | established_footnotes = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_footnotes = | managing_authorities = [[Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources (South Australia)|Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources]] | url = }} '''Minlacowie Conservation Park''' is a [[protected area]] located in the [[Yorke Peninsula]] of [[South Australia]] about {{convert|13|km|abbr=off}} west of [[Stansbury, South Australia|Stansbury]]. The conservation park was proclaimed under the ''[[National Parks and Wildlife Act 1972]]'' in 2008. The following statement of significance appears in the park’s management plan:
Minlacowie Conservation Park (28.5 hectares; proclaimed in 2008) is located about 13 kilometres west of Stansbury. The park comprises a small patch of remnant mallee/broombush vegetation in very good condition, and conserves a number of significant plant species including the nationally and state vulnerable [[Caladenia|Winter Spider-orchid]] (''Caladenia brumalis'').
The conservation park is classified as an [[International Union for Conservation of Nature|IUCN]] [[IUCN protected area categories#Category VI – Protected Area with sustainable use of natural resources|Category VI protected area]].{{cite web|title=CAPAD 2012 South Australia Summary (see 'DETAIL' tab)|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/system/files/pages/0f927a4e-336a-490c-a896-ec37874a5c73/files/capad2012sa.xlsx|work=CAPAD 2012|publisher=Australian Government - Department of the Environment|accessdate=6 February 2014|date=6 February 2014}}{{Gazetteer of Australia|name= Minlacowie Conservation Park|feature= SA0032155 }}{{cite web|title=Mainland Conservation Parks of Yorke Peninsula Management Plan 2009|url=http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/40ccb65e-c97a-4f04-af74-9e4f00b16e48/mainland-cps-of-yp-mp.pdf|publisher=Department for Environment and Heritage|accessdate=15 July 2014|page=2}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.protectedplanet.net/minlacowie-conservation-park Minlacowie Conservation Park webpage on protected planet] {{ Yorke Peninsula }} {{Protected areas of South Australia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Minlacowie Conservation Park}} [[Category:Conservation parks of South Australia]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 2008]] [[Category:2008 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Yorke Peninsula]] {{SouthAustralia-protected-area-stub}} {{Protected-area-stub}}

revision.comment: Remove 1 stray access-date. ([[User:GreenC bot/Job 5|GreenC bot job #5]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox ancient site | name = Ras ir-Raħeb Megalithic temple and Punic-Roman remains | native_name = Ras ir-Raħeb {{mt icon}} | alternate_name = | image = File:Rooms at Ras ir-Raħeb (12524088183).jpg | alt = Room footprint at Ras ir-Raħeb | caption = Foundation stones at Ras ir-Raħeb | map_type = Malta | map_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|35|54|24|N|14|19|41|E|display=inline}} | location = [[Baħrija]], [[Rabat, Malta|Rabat]], [[Malta]] | region = | type = Settlement | part_of = | length = | width = | area = | height = | builder = | material = | built = | abandoned = | epochs = Late Bronze–Early Byzantine | cultures = Borġ in-Nadur phase, Phoenician, Roman | dependency_of = | occupants = | event = | excavations = | archaeologists = | condition = | ownership = Mixed private and public | public_access = Open | website = | notes = Partly unexcavated, on headland by sheer cliffs }} '''Ras ir-Raħeb''', known also as '''Ras il-Knejjes''' is a scenic [[limestone]] [[promontory]] in north western [[Malta]], close to the [[hamlet (place)|hamlet]] of [[Baħrija]].{{cite news|last=Buġeja|first=Lino|title=Showcase of Malta’s scenic and archaeological sites|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130120/life-features/Showcase-of-Malta-s-scenic-and-archaeological-sites.454171|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=20 January 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://pleiades.stoa.org/places/462463 |title=Places: 462463 (Ras-ir Raheb Roman Farm) |author=Wilson, R., R. Talbert, S. Gillies, T. Elliott |accessdate=February 14, 2014 |publisher=Pleiades}} The [[headland]] is located in the administrative area of the [[Local councils of Malta|council]] of [[Rabat, Malta|Rabat]]. Ras ir-Raħeb lies in the north western corner of the Rabat-[[Dingli]]-[[Mdina]] [[plateau]], just off [[Fomm ir-Riħ|Fomm ir-Riħ Bay]]. It rises to 45 metres above sea level.{{cite journal|last=Buħaġiar|first=Keith|title=Baħrija: Its archaeological significance|journal=Melita Historica|year=2007|volume=XIV|issue=4|pages=357–374}} The peak allows views of the west coast of the island, as far as the cliffs of Ta' Ċenċ in [[Gozo]]. A wide variety of vegetation grows on the headland, including large populations of [[Lygeum spartum|esparto grass]] on the [[clay]] slopes in the area.{{cite news|title=Ras Ir-Raħeb fire|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2007-08-05/news/ras-ir-raheb-fire-177402/|accessdate=14 February 2014|newspaper=The Malta Independent on Sunday|date=5 August 2007}} The headland also serves as a [[pilotage|navigational marker]].{{cite news|title=Sea traffic restrictions during Commonwealth meeting|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20051028/local/sea-traffic-restrictions-during-commonwealth-meeting.73887|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=28 October 2005}} The headland incorporates the ruins of a [[Megalithic Temples of Malta|megalithic temple]], as well as [[Punic]]-[[Roman Empire|Roman]] remains.{{cite news|last=Scerri|first=Louis|title=Cremation, cart ruts, tombs, and archaeological reassessments|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130217/books/Cremation-cart-ruts-tombs-and-archaeological-reasssessments.458189|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=17 February 2013}} Scholars have been arguing about the function of these remains for decades. Interpretations differ from a [[Roman villa|domestic villa]] to a small religious [[shrine]], as well as a major [[temple]] dedicated to [[Heracles]].{{cite book|last=Sagona|first=C.|title=Punic Antiquities of Malta and Other Ancient Artefacts Held in Ecclesiastic and Private Collections|year=2006|publisher=Peeters Publishers|location=Belgium|page=14|chapter=Volume II}} The headland is also a popular [[Scuba diving|diving]] site, which also includes a cave.{{cite web|last=Vella|first=E|title=Ras ir-Raheb. Boat dive.|url=http://www.atlam.org/update/diveofthemonth.pdf|accessdate=14 February 2014}}{{cite web|title=St. Peter's Cave|url=http://www.lunadiving.com/divesite.asp?dive=25|publisher=Luna Diving|accessdate=14 February 2014}}{{cite web|title=Ras ir-Raħeb|url=http://www.sunflowerhotel.com.mt/outdooractivities/RasIrRaheb/tabid/1264/language/en-US/Default.aspx|publisher=Sunflower Hotel Malta|accessdate=14 February 2014}} The Ras ir-Raħeb coastline forms part of the Rdum Majjiesa to Ras ir-Raħeb [[marine protected area]], the first marine area to be protected in Malta, in 2005.{{cite web|last=Schembri|first=P.|title=RDUM MAJJIESA TO RAS IR-RAHEB MPA|url=https://www.um.edu.mt/science/biology/staff/profpatrickschembri/empafish/rdum_majjiesa_to_ras_ir-raheb|publisher=University of Malta|accessdate=14 February 2014}}{{cite web|title=Which are the current Marine Protected Areas of Malta?|url=https://www.mepa.org.mt/currentareas|publisher=MEPA|accessdate=14 February 2014}}{{cite news|title=Habitats of the Maltese islands (20) Marine habitats (6) – Protection of ecosystems|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20100706/opinion/habitats-of-the-maltese-islands-20.316407|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=6 July 2010}} ==Toponymy and geography== The two [[Maltese language|Maltese]] toponyms, Hermit's Headland ({{lang-mt|Ras ir-Raħeb}}) and Churches' Headland ({{lang-mt|Ras il-Knejjes}}) may indicate that the site had an established religious significance in the late [[Middle Ages]].{{cite journal|last=Buħaġiar|first=Mario|title=Two archaeological sites – Ras ir-Raħeb, Malta, and Ras il-Wardija, Gozo|journal=Melita Historica|year=1988|volume=10|issue=1|pages=69–87}} The coast between Rdum Majjiesa and Ras ir-Raħeb was earmarked and proposed for protection, in a number of local environmental heritage management documents, including The Structure Plan for the Maltese Islands{{cite book|last=Planning Services Division|first=Works Department|title=Structure Plan for the Maltese Islands|year=1990|publisher=Ministry for Development of Infrastructure|location=Malta}} and the [[United Nations Environment Programme|UNEP]]/MAP Coastal Area Management Programme (CAMP) Report for Malta.{{cite web|title=MAP CAMP Project "Malta": final integrated project document and selected thematic documents: Volume I|url=http://195.97.36.231/acrobatfiles/MTSAcrobatfiles/mts138Vol2.pdf|publisher=UNEP. Mediterranean Action Plan. Priority Actions Programme Regional Activity Centre (PAP/RAC), Malta 2003, UNEP/MAP/PAP|accessdate=15 February 2014|page=34|format=PDF}} Due to their relative inaccessibility and the shelter they provide, the cliffs and the coastline at Ras ir-Raħeb provides refuge for several [[species]] of [[Endemic Maltese wildlife|Maltese flora and fauna]]. The inaccessibility increases the [[Ornithology|ornithological]] importance of the [[coastal cliff]] habitat, given [[urban development]] decreased those habitats formerly used for breeding, feeding and [[wintering]] purposes, activities now mainly restricted to cliffs on the western coasts of Malta and Gozo. The area also hosts representatives of the main [[marine habitat]] types occurring in the [[Maltese islands]] with many species and [[ecosystem]]s of conservation importance.{{cite news|title=Il-Majjiesa/Ras ir-Raħeb area|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20110602/environment/Il-Majjiesa-Ras-ir-Ra-eb-area.368405|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=2 June 2011}} These include meadows of [[Posidonia oceanica|Posidonia seagrass]], which support a large variety of organisms for conservation interest such as the [[Pinna nobilis|noble pen clam]]. The extensive sandbanks found in inlets along this coast and beyond the seagrass meadows support diverse aquatic animals that live on the seabed. This site is a [[Natura 2000]] protected area.{{cite news|last=Sansone|first=Kurt|title=Mepa designates four new marine protected areas|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20100730/local/mepa-designates-four-new-marine-protected-areas.320242|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=30 July 2010}}{{cite news|last=Żammit|first=Anne|title=Natura 2000 – ensuring long-term survival for Europe's species|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20070408/environment/natura-2000-ensuring-long-term-survival-for-europes-species.21087|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=8 April 2007}} Ras ir-Raħeb's status as a [[marine protected area]] and its geological structure, with caves and posidonia meadows, have made it a unique and popular diving site.{{cite news|last=Cooke|first=Patrick|title=Divers call for better enforcement, protection measures at dive sites|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20100815/local/divers-call-for-better-enforcement-protection-measures-at-dive-sites.322500|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=15 August 2010}} An underwater trail for divers, marked with signs, is also present.{{cite news|last=Sansone|first=Kurt|title=Seabed signs off Għajn Tuffieħa|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20101108/local/seabed-signs-off-ghajn-tuffieha.335233|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=8 November 2010}} ==Archaeological excavations== [[File:Megaliths at Ras ir-Raħeb (12523985855).jpg|thumbnail|Megaliths at Ras ir-Raħeb]] The archaeological importance of Ras ir-Raħeb was known since the late sixteenth century, with attempts to identify these remains with the [[Juno (mythology)#Etrurian Uni.2C Hera.2C Astarte and Iuno|Fanum Iunonis]] temple mentioned by [[Cicero]].[[Cicero|Cic.]] ''Verr.'' iv. 46, 47{{cite book|last=Bosio|first=Giacomo|title=Historia della Sacra Religione et Illustrissima Militia di San Giovanni Gierosolimitano, di nuovo ristampata e dal medesimo autore ampliata et illustrata|date=1621–29|location=Rome|page=Part III 924}}{{cite book|last=Axiaq|first=M.A.|title=Relazione della nuova e grandissima devotione introdotta nella S. Grotta di S. Paolo nell’Isola di Malta|year=1610|publisher=Notitie di Malta|location=Malta|page=N L M Lib. 515, ff.21v-22.}} Other [[Renaissance]] [[historian]]s did not agree with this view, describing only the existence of "ruins and ancient factories."{{cite book|last=Abela|first=G.F.|title=Della Descrittione di Malta|year=1647|location=Malta|page=67}}{{refn|group=n| {{it icon}} "Rovine e anticaglie di fabriche."}} In 1922, the remains were brought to the notice of the [[Maltese people|Maltese]] [[archaeologist]] [[Themistocles Zammit|Themistocles Żammit]] by the owner of the land. A large, square area paved with "very regularly laid" small, baked [[tiles]], was discovered by the farmer who tilled the field. The archaeologist unearthed "a frame of stonework" as well as the remains of a door-sill. The amount of household [[pottery]], betrayed “a numerous settlement.” Żammit went on to state that "the site should be kept in mind as one that could be studied and excavated with profit."{{Harvnb|Museums Department Annual Report|1922/3|p=v}} The site was partly excavated by a team of [[Royal Navy]] officers under Capt. D. Scott and Sgn. Comdr. P. Pugh.{{Harvnb|Museums Department Annual Report|1962|p=6}} However, the exposed masonry as well as contemporary deposits had been almost completely [[Erosion|eroded]], making the interpretation of the archaeological remains very difficult. Work began in November 1961 and finished in May 1962, when a party of naval divers explored the [[seabed]] off the headland, reaching a depth of over 60 metres. A few scattered stone blocks lying in the sand were noted. The report of this excavation is brief, with the published plan of the site being inaccurate. The team was of the opinion that the place "was used as a sacred site from [[Neolithic]] times to about the 4th century AD." The site itself suggests a building complex of importance, commanding extensive sea views. It was surrounded, on at least three sides, by an [[esplanade]] delimited by a semicircular wall which extended from east to west and can be followed for a length of about 62 metres.{{refn|group=n|The esplanade and its wall are not mentioned in the Museum Annual Report accounts, nor are they listed on the excavations plan. However, they are referenced in the report ''Excavations at Ras ir-Raħeb.''}} Today, only the [[foundation stone]]s, cut in squared limestone blocks, survive but a plan of the cluster of rectangular rooms grouped round a central [[courtyard]] can still be made out. The pavement of small white [[marble]] cubes embedded in [[concrete]], and a few diamond-shaped tiles survived in one of the rooms until 1977,{{cite book|last=Lewis|first=H.|title=Ancient Malta – A Study of its Antiquities|year=1977|publisher=Colin Smythe|location=Gerrards Cross, Buckinghamshire|page=92}} but by 1988, these had disappeared. In the centre of the main room, there are two well dressed oblong stones, which were thought to form part of an [[altar]]. In the north-eastern corner, there is a long and narrow rectangular [[cistern]]. It has a circular opening dug into a block of [[limestone]], with an opening for [[rainwater]] at one end. Although no water source feeds the cistern, the permanent [[Spring (hydrology)|spring]] of Għajn Bierda, which flows a hundred yards to the south-east, may have been deviated to lower ground, providing the buildings with a year-round supply of fresh water. [[File:Ras ir-Raħeb plan stanowiska archeologicznego.png|thumbnail|left|Site plan of the Megalithic and Punic-Roman remains at Ras ir-Raħeb]] A main point of interest of the remains at Ras ir-Raħeb is the integration of two rough stone [[megaliths]] within the Punic-Roman structure. These are the remains of an earlier, [[Prehistory|prehistoric]] structure. The only other instance in Malta of the reuse of the remains of a prehistoric building is at [[Tas-Silġ]] where the rear-[[apse]] of a megalithic temple was included in building of a Punic-Roman sanctuary. These two sites share a number of similarities, such as the position of the courtyard with respect to the rest of the building – leading to the hypothesis that the Ras ir-Raħeb site may have also had a religious meaning. A reassessment of [[Ptolemy|Ptolemy’s]] descriptions attempted to link this site with a temple to [[Heracles]],{{lang|grc|Μελίτη νήσος ἐν ᾗ ... καὶ Ἡρακλέους ἱερόν.}} ''The island of [[Malta|Melite]] on which is ... and the temple of Heracles.''
{{gr icon}} {{la icon}} {{cite book|title=Claudii Ptolemaei [[Geography (Ptolemy)|Geographia]]|author=[[Claudius Ptolemy]]|editor-first=Carolus Fridericus Augustus|editor-last=Nobbe|publisher=[[Tauchnitz publishers|Carolus Tauchnitius]]|volume=I|page=246|year=1843|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4ksBAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA246#v=onepage&q&f=false|chapter=Book IV, Chapter 3 §37|language=Greek, Latin}} At [[Google Books]]. but the arguments are not conclusive.{{cite journal|last=Ventura|first=F.|title=Ptolemy’s Maltese Co-ordinates|journal=Hyphen|year=1988|volume=V|issue=6|pages=253–269}} During the 1962 excavation, a [[coin]] of [[Constantius II]] was found, hinting at a long life of the building and its possible use in early [[Christian]] times. A “great quantity of pottery” found in the cistern included the whole range of the Roman occupation. Four other coins found at the site were in an advanced stage of corrosion, with two of them being classified as Siculo-Punic. [[File:Limestone blocks (12524427284).jpg|thumbnail|Limestone blocks at the site]] Of greater interest is an [[ivory]] plaque, with a low relief of a crouching [[boar]] that is not of [[Classical Greek period|Classical Greek influence]] and may indicate the survival of Punic culture. Two clay [[satyr]] masks on vessel legs were also found, and classified as Punic. The remains of a clay figurine of a nude male youth, broken from the waist upwards, however, is probably a late [[Hellenistic]] work. Several other pieces of clay figurines, including another male nude and a draped female holding a small [[pyx]]es, a small grotesque head of a bald and bearded old man, and a fragment of a cloaked figure were collected from among the debris. Fragments of incense stands were also found.{{cite book|last=Culican|first=William|title=Leeds University Oriental Society – Near Eastern Researches II – Oriental Studies|year=1980|page=96|publisher=E. J. Brill|location=Leiden, The Netherlands|isbn=90 04 05966 0}} In addition to this site, a small quarry of unknown age lies south of these remains. It is possible that it provided the stone for the building of the complex. ==Legal status and state of conservation== [[File:Seaview from Ras ir-Raħeb (12524368614).jpg|thumbnail|Seaview from Ras ir-Raħeb]] The beauty and relative inaccessibility of Ras ir-Raħeb have made it a popular stop for [[Rambling|rambler]]s.{{cite news|last=Buġeja|first=Lino|title=Malta’s fantastic coasts beckon|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20120318/life-features/Malta-s-fantastic-coasts-beckon.411691|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=18 March 2012}}{{cite news|last=Buġeja|first=Lino|title=Ramblers seek pastures new|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20120106/local/Ramblers-seek-pastures-new.401231|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=6 January 2012}} However, this has not been without controversy,{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20080728/local/ramblers-in-protest-walk-over-access-to-fomm-ir-rih-bay.218509|title=Ramblers in protest walk over access to Fomm ir-Riħ bay|last=Micallef|first=Mark|date=28 July 2008|newspaper=Times of Malta|accessdate=15 February 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20120922/opinion/Everyone-s-right-to-ramble.437878|title=Everyone’s right to ramble|last=Buġeja|first=Lino|date=22 September 2012|newspaper=Times of Malta|accessdate=15 February 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20111027/opinion/Craving-for-a-room-for-our-view.390957|title=Craving for a room for our view|last=Buġeja|first=Lino|date=27 October 2011|newspaper=Times of Malta|accessdate=15 February 2014}} as the legal ownership of the headland is unclear.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20050119/local/ramblers-turned-away-from-site-of-historic-value.101746|title=Ramblers turned away from site of historic value|last=Cini|first=George|date=19 January 2005|newspaper=Times of Malta|accessdate=14 February 2014}} A group of ramblers were evicted from the promontory by a local hunter in late 2004. The ramblers included a number of archaeologists who wrote to the Estate Management Department asking how such an important archaeological site was out of bounds to the public.{{cite news|title=Killing Malta’s heritage softly|url=http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/2005/05/08/t21.html|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Malta Today|date=8 May 2005}} The department stated that "the land in question is in course of expropriation [...] which was expropriated by Government Notice 498 dated July 29, 1975. As such, legally land in question is still {{Sic|privately|-|hide=y}}owned since deed of transfer is not finalised."{{cite news|last=Debono|first=James|title=Fighting for access to Fomm ir-Rih beach|url=http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/2006/01/15/t15.html|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Malta Today|date=15 January 2006}} However, a ministerial declaration in 2006, by [[Tonio Borg|Tonio Borġ]], who was then Minister of Justice and Home Affairs,{{cite news|last=Grech|first=Herman|title=Tonio Borg nominated for vacant EU post|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20121021/local/Tonio-Borg-nominated-for-vacant-EU-post.441899|accessdate=14 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=21 October 2012}} concluded that "areas that have been taken over by [[Government of Malta|Government]] through a [[President of Malta|President]]'s proclamation prior to 1994, even though not paid for by the Government, such as Ras ir-Raħeb, can be legally accessed by the public and not even the owner can prohibit access."{{cite web|title=Resume` of contents of Meeting which RAM had with Dr Tonio Borg, Minister of Justice and Home Affairs and that was held at the Auberge d’Aragon on Tuesday 9th May 2006.|url=http://www.ramblersmalta.org/dloads/RAM_Tonio_Borg.doc|publisher=Ramblers Association Malta|accessdate=14 February 2014|date=9 May 2006}} The Punic-Roman remains were officially scheduled in 1998.{{cite web|title=No. 278, Scheduling of property|url=https://www.mepa.org.mt/file.aspx?f=1007|publisher=Gazzetta tal-Gvern ta' Malta|accessdate=7 June 2016|date=3 April 1998}} A large [[wildfire]] burnt a significant swathe of the coastline in 2007, with various [[NGO]]s calling the general public to be vigilant and report abuse, in an area plagued by vandalism and illegal construction.{{cite web|title=ILLEGAL STRUCTURE DEMOLISHED IN WIED GERŻUMA|url=http://www.mepa.org.mt/outlook11-article6|publisher=MEPA|accessdate=14 February 2014|year=2011}}{{cite news|title=Mepa demolishes illegal structure in protected countryside|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20110205/local/mepa-demolishes-illegal-structure-in-protected-countryside.348693|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=Times of Malta|date=5 February 2011}} Some of the ancient limestone remains found on site were vandalised in 2016. Holes were drilled into the blocks, with steel rods and hooks inserted into the remains to allow [[rock climbing]] along the nearby cliffs.{{cite news|url=http://www.inewsmalta.com/dart/20160601-fdalijiet-stori-mtaqqbin-bi-drillers-adid-at-tixbit|title=Fdalijiet storiċi 'mtaqqbin' bi drillers u b'ħadid għat-tixbit|date=1 June 2016|newspaper=iNewsMalta|accessdate=7 June 2016}} In 2016, five [[Maltese units of measurement#Land|tumoli of land]] forming part of the Ras ir-Raħeb headland was placed for sale - including the ancient remains found on the site.{{cite news|title=Fdalijiet Rumani f'Ras ir-Raheb għall-bejgħ!|url=http://www.inewsmalta.com/dart/20160517-fdalijiet-rumani-ras-ir-raheb-all-bejg|accessdate=7 June 2016|newspaper=iNewsMalta|date=17 May 2016}} Heritage experts declared that while ownership of the land in questions appeared to be unclear, the recent introduction of a public domain law in Malta ought to exclude the purchase or sale of sites like Ras ir-Raħeb. In July 2016, [[Friends of the Earth (Malta)|Friends of the Earth]], a local environmental committee, filed an application requesting that Ras ir-Raħeb along with six other sites be designated officially as public domain.{{cite web|title=Friends of the Earth Malta proposes seven sites for ‘Public Domain Act’ protection|url=http://www.foemalta.org/web/news/98-2016/300-friends-of-the-earth-malta-proposes-seven-sites-for-public-domain-act-protection|accessdate=10 September 2016|date=21 July 2016|publisher=Friends of the Earth, Malta}}{{cite news|title=eNGO proposes seven sites for Public Domain Act|url=http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/lifestyle/environment/67783/engo_proposes_seven_sites_for_public_domain_act#.V9QkkJh97Dc|accessdate=10 September 2016|newspaper=MaltaToday|date=21 July 2016}} ==See also== {{Commons category|Ras ir-Raħeb}} *[[Tas-Silġ]] *[[Geography of Malta]] *[[Outline of Malta]] *[[Endemic Maltese wildlife]] == Notes and references == '''Notes''' {{Reflist|group=n}} '''References''' {{Reflist|colwidth=25em}} '''Bibliography''' {{refbegin}} * {{cite book|last=Abela|first=G.F.|title= Della Descrittione di Malta|publisher= |location=Malta|year=1647|ref=harv|postscript=}} * {{cite book|last=Axiaq|first=M.A.|title= Relazione della nuova e grandissima devotione introdotta nella S. Grotta di S. Paolo nell’Isola di Malta|publisher= |location=Malta|year=1610|ref=harv|postscript=}} * {{cite book|last=Culican|first=W. |title=Leeds University Oriental Society – Near Eastern Researches II – Oriental Studies|publisher= E. J. Brill|location=Leiden, The Netherlands|year=1980|isbn= 90 04 05966 0|ref=harv|postscript=}} * {{cite book|last=Bosio|first=G.|title= Historia della Sacra Religione et Illustrissima Militia di San Giovanni Gierosolimitano, di nuovo ristampata e dal medesimo autore ampliata et illustrata|publisher= |location=Rome|year=1621–29|ref=harv|postscript=}} * {{cite book|last=Lewis|first=H.|title=Ancient Malta – A Study of its Antiquities|publisher=Colin Smythe |location=Gerrards Cross, Buckinghamshire|year=1977|ref=harv|postscript=}} * {{cite book|last=Sagona|first=C.|title= Punic Antiquities of Malta and Other Ancient Artefacts Held in Ecclesiastic and Private Collections|publisher= Peeters Publishers|location=Belgium|year=2006|ref=harv|postscript=}} {{refend}} == External links == [[Image:Muziy SPb 2010 3392.jpg|thumb|Headquarters of the Russian Geographical Society]]
The '''Russian Geographical Society''' (Russian: Ру́сское географи́ческое о́бщество «РГО») (RGO) is a [[learned society]] based in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]]. It promotes exploration and geography with research programs in fields including [[oceanography]] and [[ethnography]].
==History==
===Imperial Geographical Society===
The society was founded on 6 (18) August 1845 in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]]. Prior to the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]], it was known as the '''Imperial Russian Geographical Society'''.
===Founding members=== The founding members of the Imperial Russian Geographical Society included:<ref>Pyotr Semyonov-Tyan-Shansky, vol. 1, p. 2-3.</ref>
*{{Interlanguage link multi|Konstantin Arseniev|ru|3=Арсеньев, Константин Иванович}} *[[Friedrich Wilhelm Rembert von Berg|Friedrich (Fyodor) von Berg]] *[[Karl Ernst von Baer]] *[[Ferdinand von Wrangel]] *{{Interlanguage link multi|Platon Chikhachov|WD=Q3391999}} *[[Vladimir Dal]] *[[Gregor von Helmersen]] *[[William Herbert Hobbs]] *{{Interlanguage link multi|Peter von Köppen|WD=Q2988972}} *[[Adam Johann von Krusenstern|Adam Johann (Ivan) von Krusenstern]] *{{Interlanguage link multi|Alexey Levshin|WD=Q4272921}} *[[Fyodor Litke]] *[[Mikhail Muravyov-Vilensky]] *[[Vladimir Odoyevsky]] *[[Vasily Alekseevich Perovsky]] *[[Pyotr Ivanovich Ricord]] *{{Interlanguage link multi|Mikhail Vronchenko|ru|3=Вронченко, Михаил Павлович}} *[[Friedrich Georg Wilhelm von Struve|Friedrich Georg Wilhelm (Vasily) von Struve]]
The Society's official presidents were [[Grand Duke Konstantin Nikolayevich of Russia]] in 1845-92 and [[Grand Duke Nicholas Mikhailovich of Russia]] in 1892-1917, but actually it was run by the Vice-Presidents: Fyodor Litke (1845–50, 1855–57), [[Count]] [[Mikhail Nikolayevich Muravyov-Vilensky|Mikhail Muravyov]] (1850–57), [[Pyotr Semyonov-Tyan-Shansky]] (1873–1914), and [[Yuly Shokalsky]] (1914–31).
The filial societies were established at the Caucasus (1850), Irkutsk (1851), Vilnius (1867), Orenburg (1868), Kiev (1873), Omsk (1877), and other cities.
The Society organized and funded the expeditions of [[Richard Maack]], [[Pyotr Kropotkin]], Semyonov-Tyan-Shansky, [[Nikolai Przhevalsky]], [[Nikolai Miklukho-Maklai]], [[Pyotr Kozlov]], [[Vladimir Obruchev]], and [[Lev Berg]]. It helped set up the first [[polar station]]s in [[Russia]] and was one of the first to publish detailed studies of the [[Russian folklore]] and Ukrainian fairs.
The Society pioneered the systematic exploration of the Northern [[Urals]] in 1847-50, of the farthest reaches of the [[Amur River]] in 1854-63, of the vast areas of [[Kashgaria]], [[Dzungaria]], and [[Mongolia]] from the 1870s onward.
By 1917 the RGO was composed of eleven subdivisions and 1,000 members.
===Constantine Medal=== The Constantine Medal was a gold medal worth 200 silver roubles and was the highest award of the Imperial Russian Geographical Society. It was established and named after the Society’s first chairman, Great Duke Constantine and was awarded from 1849 to 1929 to explorers who had made a significant geographical discovery or to authors of outstanding publications in geography, ethnography or Russian statistics. From 1924 to 1929 the Medal was referred to as “The highest award of the Russian Geographical Society”. <ref> {{cite web|url= http://www.rgo.ru/en/society/awards/constantine-medal-irgs|title= Constantine Medal of the IRGS|publisher= Russian Geographical Society|accessdate = 25 August 2015}} </ref>
Recipients of the medal included: *1849 [[Ernst Reinhold Hofmann]], for his excellent work during the first expedition of the Russian Geographical Society to the Northern Urals (first award) *1858 [[Ivan Aksakov]], for his research into trade fairs in Ukraine *1859 [[Peter Carl Ludwig Schwarz|Ludwig Schwarz]] *1863 [[Vladimir Dahl]], for the Explanatory Dictionary of the Russian Language *1864 Ivashintsov Nikolay Alekseevich, for his long-term efforts to research the [[Caspian Sea]] <ref> {{cite book|title=The Caspian Sea Encyclopedia|first= Igor|last = Zonn|page= 228}} </ref> *1874 [[Nikolay Przhevalsky]], for his pre-eminent scientific research, geographical discoveries and travels to Mongolia and the Tangut land *1878 [[Adolf Erik Nordenskiöld|Adolf Erik Nordensheld]], for his voyage and research in the Arctic Ocean along the northern coast of Western and Eastern Siberia *1898 [[Gustav Radde|Dr Gustav Radde]] *1900 [[Vladimir Obruchev]], for his publications on Asian geology *1902 [[Pyotr Kozlov]], for the 1899-1901 expedition to Tibet *1905 [[Alexander Kolchak]], for participation in Baron E. Toll’s expedition, and for the journey to Bennett Island in particular *1905 [[Carl Friedrich Schmidt (1832)|Friedrich Schmidt]] *1907 [[Grigory Grumm-Grzhimaylo |Grigoriy Grum-Grzhimailo]], for all his works in Asian geography and for his “Description of a journey in Western China. Volume III” *1907 [[Fridtjof Nansen]], for his remarkable feats, which constitute a whole era in the Arctic Ocean exploration *1914 [[Boris Vilkitsky]], for hydrographic expeditions in the Arctic Sea.
===All-Union Geographical Society=== [[Image:Rgolibrary.jpg|thumb|Library of the Russian Geographical Society in 1916.]] The Society changed its name to the State Geographical Society in 1926 and to the Geographical Society of the USSR in 1938. After Shokalsky its presidents were [[geneticist]] [[Nikolai Vavilov]] (1931–40), [[zoologist]] [[Lev Berg]] (1940–1950), [[parasitology|parasitologist]] [[Evgeny Pavlovsky]] (1952–64), [[glaciologist]] [[Stanislav Kalesnik]] (1964–77), [[polar explorer]] [[Aleksei Treshnikov]] (1977–91). The Society has convened numerous congresses and has awarded four types of medals, Big Gold Medal (tri-annual) and three, named after Litke, Semyonov, Przhevalsky (bi-annual),<ref>http://pegion.ru/58df61cf841a.htm "Earth and people" magazine about RGO medals</ref> and also [[Semen Dezhnev]] prize (bi-annual). By 1970, it had published more than 2,000 volumes of geographical literature, including the annual ''Zapiski'' (since 1846) and ''Izvestiya'' (since 1865).
===Post-Soviet era=== The society reverted to its original name upon the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991. The main offices of the Society are in St. Petersburg.
In September 2010, [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco]] was made an honorary member of the Society.
Since 2002 the society has sponsored an annual seasonal ice base in the Arctic, [[Barneo|Camp Barneo]].<ref>[http://www.barneo.ru/ Ice camp Барнео]</ref>
==Divisions== The Imperial Society comprised four departments:
===Department of Physical Geography===
===Department of Mathematical Geography===
===Department of Ethnography=== Nikolai Nadezhdin was involved in the foundation of this department, when the RGO was originally set up. During the 1850s and 1860s the [[ethnography|ethnographic]] division gathered and published material such as works of folklore and the ''byt'' or "way of life" which they regarded as reflecting the "essence" of the indigenous people of the Russian Empire. In 1909 [[Dmitry Nikolayevich Anuchin]], [[Vladimir Bogdanov]] and [[Vsevolod Miller]] convened the ethnographic sub-section of the [[Twelfth Congress of Russian Natural Scientists and Physicians]] held in Moscow. Here they pushed for more professionalism to distinguish ethnographers from missionaries and amateurs.
In 1917 [[David Zolotarev]] and [[Nikolai Mogilyansky]] of the RGO participated in the [[Commission for the Study of the Tribal Composition of the Population of the Borderlands of Russia]].
===Department of Statistics===
== Further reading == *[[Pyotr Semyonov-Tyan-Shansky]]. ''История полувековой деятельности Императорского Русского географического общества''. Volumes 1-3. SPb, 1896. *[[Lev Berg]]. ''Всесоюзное Географическое общество за 100 лет. 1845-1945''. Moscow-Leningrad, 1946. *''Географическое общество за 125 лет''. Leningrad, 1970. *Hirsch, Francine. 2005. ''Empire of Nations: Ethnographic Knowledge and the Making of the Soviet Union''. Ithaca, NY: Cornell University Press. {{ISBN|0-8014-4273-7}}
==See also== *[[List of Russian explorers]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.rgo.ru Official website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080316100425/http://www.vitiaz.ru/congress/en/thesis/70.html The contribution of the Russian Geographical Society into the history of the ocean studies]

{{Multiple issues| {{expert-subject|Statistics|date=December 2010}} {{refimprove|date=September 2010}} }} '''Spatial dependence''' is the spatial relationship of variable values (for themes defined over space, such as [[rainfall]]) or locations (for themes defined as objects, such as cities). Spatial dependence is measured as the existence of [[statistical independence|statistical dependence]] in a collection of [[random variables]], each of which is associated with a different [[geographical location]]. Spatial dependence is of importance in applications where it is reasonable to postulate the existence of corresponding set of random variables at locations that have not been included in a sample. Thus [[rainfall]] may be measured at a set of rain gauge locations, and such measurements can be considered as outcomes of random variables, but rainfall clearly occurs at other locations and would again be random. Because [[rainfall]] exhibits properties of [[autocorrelation]], spatial interpolation techniques can be used to estimate [[rainfall]] amounts at locations near measured locations.
As with other types of statistical dependence, the presence of spatial dependence generally leads to estimates of an average value from a sample being less accurate than had the samples been independent, although if negative dependence exists a sample average can be better than in the independent case. A different problem than that of estimating an overall average is that of [[spatial interpolation]]: here the problem is to estimate the unobserved random outcomes of variables at locations intermediate to places where measurements are made, on that there is spatial dependence between the observed and unobserved random variables.
Tools for exploring spatial dependence include: [[spatial correlation]], [[spatial covariance function]]s and [[semivariogram]]s.
Methods for spatial interpolation include [[Kriging]], which is a type of [[best linear unbiased prediction]].
The topic of spatial dependence is of importance to [[geostatistics]] and [[spatial analysis]].
==See also== * [[Spatial analysis#Spatial dependency or auto-correlation|Spatial analysis]] * [[Geostatistics]]
==References== * Journel, A G and Huijbregts, C J, ''Mining Geostatistics'', [[Academic Press]] Inc, London
{{DEFAULTSORT:Spatial Dependence}} [[Category:Spatial data analysis]] [[Category:Independence (probability theory)]]

{{short description|A large shallow body of salt water of the Mesozoic and Cenozoic Eras}} <!-- [[WP:NFCC]] violation: [[Image:Early Eocene Arctic basin.PNG|thumb|The continental configuration during the Early Eocene (49 million years ago) showing the Turgay Strait.]] --> '''The Turgai''' (or Turgay) '''Sea''' or '''Turgai Strait''', also known as the '''West Siberian Sea''', was a large shallow body of salt water (an epicontinental or [[Epeiric Sea|epeiric sea]]) of the [[Mesozoic]] and [[Cenozoic]] [[era (geology)|Era]]s. It extended north of the present-day [[Caspian Sea]] to the "paleo-Arctic" region, and was in existence from [[Middle Jurassic]] to [[Oligocene]] times, from approximately 160 to 29 million years ago.<ref>Briggs, John C. ''Global Biogeography.'' Amsterdam, Elsevier Science, 1995; pp. 71, 76, 84, 88, and ff.</ref>
The Turgai Sea was not absolutely continuous throughout this entire era, though it was a persistent and predominating feature in its region; it "fragmented southern Europe and southwestern Asia into many large islands, and separated Europe from Asia."<ref>Duellman, William Edward. ''Biology of Amphibians.'' Baltimore, Johns Hopkins University Press, 1994; p. 480.</ref>
The division of the [[Eurasia]]n landmass by the Turgai Sea had the effect of isolating animal populations.<ref name="Duellman 1986">{{cite book |title=Biology of Amphibians |last= Duellman |first= William E. |year=1986 |publisher= JHU Press|isbn=9780801847806 |quote=Otherwise, most, if not all, continental masses were united into a single land mass — Pangaea. ... (M) Leiopelmatidae (L) Discoglossidae (U) Palaeobatrachidae (U) Cretaceous, 135 m.y. Turgai Sea separated east and west Eurasia |page=479 }}</ref> Perhaps best known to laypeople were the horned [[dinosaur]]s called [[Ceratopsia]] of the [[Cretaceous Period]], which were restricted to Asia and western North America (which were connected for much of this era).<ref>Culver, Stephen J., and Peter Franklin Rawson. ''Biotic Response to Global Change: The Last 145 Million Years.'' Cambridge, Cambridge University Press, 2000; p. 319.</ref> The existence of the Turgai Sea also restricted various freshwater fish and amphibians.
The Turgai Sea derives its name from a region of modern-day [[Kazakhstan]], with its [[Turgai River]] and [[Turgai Valley]].
==See also== * {{annotated link|Rheic Ocean}} * {{annotated link|Sundance Sea}} * {{annotated link|Tethys Ocean}}
==References== <references/>

{{ref improve|date=April 2013}} [[Image:USID P-Tag On Wrist With Barcode.jpg|thumb|200px|USID Patient-tag.
''Foto: Sonitor Technologies'']] '''Ultrasound Identification''' is a [[real-time locating]] system (RTLS) or [[indoor positioning system]] (IPS) technology used to automatically determine and identify the location of objects with room accuracy. The approach is using simple, inexpensive nodes (badges/tags) attached to the surface of persons, objects and devices, which then transmit an ultrasound signal to communicate their locations to microphone sensors. Because ultrasound signal [[wavelength]]s have short reach, they are confined to lesser distant locations than with wireless transmissions with higher susceptibility to multiple reflection, multipath and through-the-wall multiple room responses. Hence ultrasound-based RTLS is considered a more robust alternative to passive [[radio-frequency identification]] (pRFID) and even to active radio-frequency identification (aRFID) in complex indoor environments (such as hospitals), where radio waves get multiply transmitted and reflected, thereby compromising the positioning accuracy. Generally the ultrasound signal does not interfere with sensitive medical equipment.Greenemeier, Larry. [https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/indoor-positioning-system/ "A Positioning System That Goes Where GPS Can't"], ''[[Scientific American]]'', 2008-01-23. Retrieved on 2008-04-04. A handicap of ultrasound nodes is the exposition of the sound transducer at the surface, which prevents from hermetically encapsulating the node. Vapour sterilisation is not offered with these nodes. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Automatic identification and data capture]] [[Category:Geolocation]] [[Category:Ubiquitous computing]]

{{refimprove|date=July 2008}}
'''Walt Disney Cartoon Classics''' was a series of cartoon compilations from [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]]. It was one of their first attempts to put cartoons on home video, after [[Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck Cartoon Collections]].
==Cartoon Classics: Version One== The first 14 volumes, from 1983–1986, came with six or seven cartoons and ran from 30–60 minutes. In addition, ''[[The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh]]'' was also released in the Walt Disney Cartoon Classics series.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00004CTY2|title=The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh|publisher=|via=Amazon}}</ref> The titles of all 14 volumes and their cartoons are as follows.
===Chip 'N' Dale with Donald Duck (1983)=== #''[[Chip an' Dale]]'' (1947) #''[[Winter Storage]]'' (1949) #''[[Up a Tree (1955 film)|Up a Tree]]'' (1955) #''[[Three for Breakfast]]'' (1948) #''[[Out on a Limb (cartoon short)|Out on a Limb]]'' (1950) #''[[Corn Chips]]'' (1951) #''[[Out of Scale]]'' (1951)
===Pluto (1983)=== #''[[Pluto's Fledgling]]'' (1948) #''[[The Pointer]]'' (1939) #''[[The Legend of Coyote Rock]]'' (1945) #''[[In Dutch]]'' (1946) #''[[Private Pluto]]'' (1943) #''[[Bone Trouble]]'' (1940) #''[[Camp Dog]]'' (1950)
===[[Scary Tales]] (1983)=== #''[[Donald Duck and the Gorilla]]'' (1944) #''[[Duck Pimples]]'' (1945) #''[[The Skeleton Dance]]'' (1929) #''[[The Haunted House (1929 film)|The Haunted House]]'' (1929) #''[[Donald's Lucky Day]]'' (1939) #''[[Pluto's Judgement Day]]'' (1935)

==Limited Gold Editions== In 1984 and 1985, the "Limited Gold Editions" I and II came out with a historical introduction documentary to each video, like the first series, the second series had six or seven cartoons, but with the exceptions of "How the Best Was Won: 1933-1960", which had five cartoons, and "Disney's Best: The Fabulous '50s", which had four cartoons. LGE I videos all have the documentary about Walt Disney's early start and the first original Mickey Mouse. LGE II videos each have different documentaries focusing on histories of the specific characters/themes of the video. Including [[Mickey Mouse]], [[Donald Duck]], [[Goofy]], [[Pluto (Disney)|Pluto]], Disney's war cartoons, [[Silly Symphonies]], and the Academy Award winning shorts. These historical introduction documentaries also include interviews with the likes of [[Jack Hannah]], [[Clarence Nash]], [[Jack Kinney]], and archival footage of [[Walt Disney]] himself. In 1986, the "Limited Gold Editions I" was released on VHS in the United Kingdom, and laserdisc only in Japan, CAV, and bilingual. The 14 titles are as follows:

==Cartoon Classics: Version Two== In 1987, another series of "Cartoon Classics" was released, with 14 volumes, as well as a "Special Edition" series. Volumes 1-5 were released on May 19, 1987. Volumes 6-10 were released on October 6, 1987. Volumes 11 and 12 were released on August 31, 1989. Volumes 13 and 14 were released on October 19, 1990. The first "Special Edition" was released on November 15, 1988. The three "Special Edition" videos were released on June 19, 1992. The shorts featured on volumes 1-5 were all new-to-VHS in the United States at the time, while shorts featured on all subsequent volumes are duplicated from the earlier "Cartoon Classics" series and other early Disney VHS releases. The sole exception is ''[[The Big Wash]]'', which made its VHS debut on ''Fun on the Job''.
Between each short are clips from other cartoons, redubbed with new voices to link the featured cartoons together.

== Disney's Valentine Collection == These three videos came out originally for Valentine's Day in 1995-96. They are still released almost every year around the beginning of January through the middle of February, and retail for around $10.00 each. *''[[Love Tales]]'' (January 13, 1995) *''[[Mickey Loves Minnie]]'' (January 9, 1996) *''[[Sweetheart Stories]]'' (January 9, 1996)
